section.title: have / get something done
section.sectiontitle: Use the structure to have (or get) something done to talk about arranging for something to be done by someone else. We use the form have (or get) + object + past participle.
section.text1: Somebody dyes my hair for me.
section.text1a: I have my hair dyed once every six months.
section.text2: Somebody is decorating their house for them.
section.text2a: They're having their whole house decorated at the moment.
section.sectiontitle2: We also use have (or get) something done to talk about things that happen to us or to describe an 'experience'.
section.text3a: I had my bike stolen last week.
section.text4a: They got all their carpets ruined in the flood.

section.title: have / get something done
section.sectiontitle: We can use get + object + past participle to mean 'finish doing something'. We don't use have + object + past participle with this meaning.
section.text1: I need to finish my homework.
section.text1a: I need to get my homework done.
section.text2: After we've finished cleaning up, we can have dinner.
section.text2a: When we get this mess cleaned up, we can have dinner.
